results.title: Albert Camus: a self-portrait
results.creator_credit: Learning Corporation of America, Fred Orjain and Georges Rouquier
results.brief_description: An examination of the writing and philosophy of Albert Camus. This documentary traces the genesis of Camus’ existentialism in his relationship to the geography and culture of Algeria. Born of French parents but growing up among Arabs, Camus’ exploration of the agony of human separation reflects his own dichotomous identity. This film also includes a filmed conversation with the writer in which he talks about his love for theatre, football and the importance of achieving personal happiness in a world in which we are condemned to suffer the agonising silence of the unknown Universe. Excerpts from his novels and essays are read throughout the film.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Learning Corporation of America, Fred Orjain and Georges Rouquier

results.title: Albert Camus
results.brief_description:
Albert Camus, born in Mondovi (Algeria) on 7 November 1913, earned a worldwide reputation as a novelist and essayist and won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1957. Through his writing, and in some measure against his will, he became the leading moral voice of his generation during the 1950s. At the height of his fame, Camus died in an automobile accident in 1960. This documentary, made for TV, discusses his work and in particular his relationship to the Algerian landscape. Contains interviews with Jules Roy, Mouloud Mammeri, Francis Jeanson, Jean Pellegri and Pascal Piat.

Credits: Producer, Cecile Clairval ; director, Paul Vecchiali ; photography, Jacques Duhamel.
Cast: Julien Guiomar, Djelloul Beghoura [narration only].

results.title: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.brief_description: Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. It inspired both cinéma vérité and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s intimate portraits of society and herself.
results.title_for_label: Albert and David Maysles filming Big Edie and Little Edie in Grey Gardens
results.description: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.
description_for_label: Documentarians develop camera techniques to access, interpret and compose notions of truth. Dziga Vertov’s kino-pravda (“film truth”) concept was premised on the camera’s ability to reveal truth. In the 1960s, it inspired the development of both cinéma vérité (“truthful cinema”) and direct cinema, which informed Albert and David Maysles’ intimate ‘fly-on-the-wall’ style and Agnès Varda’s use of a handheld camera to create a portrait of society and herself.

results.title: Albatross Island
results.creator_credit: ABC-TV (Australia), Robert Horne and Ken Taylor
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Wild Australia”.
Describes Albatross Island (Tasmania), the home of the white capped Albatrosses. Reveals various aspects of their life.

results.title: Albany whaling
results.brief_description: Recounts the history of whaling on Australia’s West Coast with rare footage from early twentieth century to the last whale to be taken by the Cheynes Beach company. Includes scenes of harpooning with the grenade-head gun and the confrontation of Dr Jim Cairns’ Greenpeace Group and Albany citizens who felt that closure would endanger their homes and livings.

results.title: ALB - Whispers Under the Moonlight (2014)
results.brief_description: This music video for ALB’s ‘Whispers Under the Moonlight’ claims to be the world’s first ‘Trojan Horse Music Video’. In order to initially play the video and take part, users download a file to their computer which then initiates a series of benign computer takeovers as part of an interactive art installation on the users computer.

constellations_other.name: Hack the planet
constellations_other.description: How do you represent something that's... kinda boring to look at, like hacking, when you're operating in a visual medium like film, TV and videogames?

results.title: Alaska: the Alaska experience
results.creator_credit: Sonoma Video, Michael Heumann and Suzie Heumann
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
Visit vast Alaska and its Northern lights, active volcanos, mountains, lakes and rivers. Alaska is the country of the unexpected. People can sometimes be found fishing at midnight and sunset can be at noon. Take a cruise through the inside passage, home of whales, seals and thousands of birds. Visit Ketchika where the people have largely kept to their traditional ways, and Sitka and its Russian architecture. At Juneau, visit the Red Dog Saloon and at Anchorage, Alaska’s largest city, watch a canoe race and ride a hot air balloon. Meet the locals of Alaska, the Eskimos, Indians and Aleuts.

results.title: Alaska: reservoir of resources
results.creator_credit: EB Films and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film depicts the timber industry in Aalska in its early stages. Also shows salmon fishing during the short Summer season when 100s of millions of pounds of fish are netted under government supervision. Within the two months of the fishing and canning season many millions of dollars are made from this production. Gold mining is also carried out using cannon jets of water. During the short Summer season a variety of products are produced on the farms.

results.title: Alaska: our pioneer heritage...
results.creator_credit: Pan American World Airways and Don Horter
results.brief_description: Discusses industries and the pattern of life in Alaska. The aeroplane has played an important part in the development of this rugged and sparsely-populated country by carrying supplies and goods from city to city and enabling posts in the outback to be established. Fishing is the largest industry, but lumbering and gold mining are important. Eskimos are employed in selling furs and artistic ornaments to tourists. Many visitors come to the country to hunt big game, fish and observe the beauties of snow and ice.
